posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked:
Guys,

I was watching my mom (and I guess this apply to other less tech savvy users) using signal and I noticed her difficulties in identifying which chats are individual (1-1 conversations) and which are group messages.

Is there a way of making it easier for users to distinguish between them?

I thought of a small visual indication on the chat list or maybe specific tabs for individual messages and group messages just like we have now for calls.

Did anyone notice this happen to a friend or older relative as well?

Thanks in advance

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: A suggestion of tabs would be: 1-1 messages, group messages, stories and calls.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: Usually naming the chats is the solution

I mean… Isn’t that the point of naming threads?

I would like to see an option to have a default name for chats, like mms used to just be a list of names.
Set a picture for the group that indicates it is a group chat and give it a name that is not as easy to confuse with a contact name (include the word “group” or something similar if you have to).

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked:
I want every user to be as autonomous using Signal as possible.

This is a “solution” (workaround actually) only if the user knows beforehand which chat is a one on one conversation or a group conversation.

I try to provide as much support as I can for my mother so she keeps using Signal, so I would gladly change the group chats’ backgrounds or rename the groups that she is a member and I eventually administer.

BUT…

She is in groups which I am not a member and the groups change more often than I can usually keep up with the backgrounds and naming scheme.

SO…

What is so bad about this proposal of Signal app clearly identifying on the message list which messages are one on one conversations and which messages are group conversations?

I understand this might not be a priority right know, but why not leave it on the backlog for maturation and to check if other users have the same need as my mom?

Bests,

GuiDoSignal:

What is so bad about this proposal of Signal app clearly identifying on the message list which messages are one on one conversations and which messages are group conversations?

Nobody thinks the proposal is bad. People just want to help using the things available right now. In fact, i would very much like Signal to put group chats in a separate tab, now that stories and calls already have a dedicated tab.
If you do not set a picture for a group at all, then the default icon is simply a circle with more than one person symbol inside. I would assume that no single contact has that as a contract picture.

Also, below the group name in group chats, the group member names are listed. One on one chats show nothing in that location, or “✓ Verified” if you’ve verified their safety number.

There are already plenty of indicators of what type of chat it is.
I may be wrong, but group chats might also not show anything there if you haven’t verified anyone.

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked:
Yes, but I am referring to the screen before, i.e., where the user see all the current chats.

I agree that the user has plenty information about that when he/she is already looking the contents of a specific conversation.

This is why I think that the separation into different tabs is not so bad

posts.name: Kevin Brubeck Unhammer
posts.cooked:
The Send button should be different if sending to several people. I am not a designer and this looks like crap, but something to indicate 1

vs many

so that as your finger is hovering over send you might notice “oh I’m in a group phew”
I feel like there are already enough ways to distinguish a contact from a group but mainly: in a group you see the names of the partecipants under the group’s name.

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: Yes, but these are “inside” the conversation, but not from the conversations list.
In the conversation list you always see in bold the name of the message’s sender.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: And there’s also like… the group’s name. Unless you name your group similarly to a contact and give it a picture similar to that of a contact’s, that’s already three markers for groups vs 1-on-1 chats.

posts.name: Kevin Brubeck Unhammer
posts.cooked: And yet people keep sending messages to groups thinking they’re replying to 1-on-1. All my group chats are full of Message deleted

Yeah agreed, this definitely happens with my relatives and friend groups very frequently, even though we use named chats. Mix of savvy and novice users, it comes for us all sooner or later.

I think it’s especially challenging when you’re replying to a notification on mobile where you see the sender but not the full chat name.

One good unobtrusive UI hint might be simply a distinct color palette or indicator for group chats.
